Prove that, for any finite set $A\subset\mathbb{N}$, there exist $a,b\in A$ such that\[\mathrm{gcd}(a,b)\leq a/\lvert A\rvert.\]



A conjecture of Graham \cite{Gr70}, who also conjectured that (assuming $A$ itself has no common divisor) the only cases where equality is achieved are when $A=\{1,\ldots,n\}$ or $\{L/1,\ldots,L/n\}$ (where $L=\mathrm{lcm}(1,\ldots,n)$) or $\{2,3,4,6\}$.

Proved for all sufficiently large sets (including the sharper version which characterises the case of equality) independently by Szegedy \cite{Sz86} and Zaharescu \cite{Za87}.

Proved for all sets by Balasubramanian and Soundararajan \cite{BaSo96}.




References


[BaSo96] Balasubramanian, R. and Soundararajan, K., On a conjecture of R. L. Graham. Acta Arith. (1996), 1-38.

[Gr70] Graham, R., Unsolved problem 5749. Amer. Math. Monthly (1970), 775.

[Sz86] Szegedy, M., The solution of Graham's greatest common divisor problem. Combinatorica (1986), 67-71.

[Za87] Zaharescu, Alexandru, On a conjecture of Graham. J. Number Theory (1987), 33-40.
